awd_titl_txt: A Workshop Promoting Introduction to Engineering at Liberal Arts Colleges
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will conduct a workshop to give faculty from liberal arts colleges the tools they need to offer an introductory course in engineering.  Exposing students at liberal arts colleges to engineering will expand a little used path into the engineering profession with the potential to increase the gender and racial diversity of the field. The workshop will teach faculty from science departments at liberal arts colleges to offer an introduction to engineering course and provide them with the curriculum and supplies necessary to get started.   Liberal arts faculty have already expressed a desire to increase the exposure of liberal arts students to engineering as a career option. Liberal arts colleges have long supplied capable and well-qualified entrants into professions such as law, business, and medicine.  The career path of a liberal arts bachelor's degree in science combined with a graduate engineering degree represents a highly achievable route to the benefits of an engineering career for liberal arts students and provides the engineering profession with a potential infusion of individuals from the gender and ethnic diversity contained in liberal arts institutions.

The lack of gender and ethnic diversity in engineering merits aggressive exploration of other viable paths into the profession. Professions such as law, business, and medicine are more diverse than engineering, possibly due in part to the greater number of pathways into the profession. Liberal arts students pursue careers in law, business, and medicine but seldom engineering.  Engineering has benefited little from the talent pool represented by liberal arts schools in part because the usual path into engineering demands an early commitment on the part of the student to pursue engineering. However, students who complete an undergraduate major in science or mathematics are able to pursue graduate degrees in engineering by completing necessary prerequisites as part of a master's degree program. This proposal will pilot test a design-based introduction to engineering course that can be taught by science faculty and that will be suitable for liberal arts students.  This course will help students to become aware of the option of the liberal arts science major combined with a graduate engineering degree. This engineering career path could be a viable replacement for the largely disused 3-2 liberal arts and engineering dual degree programs.

por.por_cntn:
This project conducted a series of workshops to improve the ability of introduction to engineering courses to attract students into engineering from a wide range of backgrounds.  The workshops addressed the need to assist faculty in designing introduction to engineering courses that can attract and encourage students with a tentative interest in engineering.  The project considered that the engineering profession is less diverse than other professions because, currently, most programs effectively require students to decide to pursue an engineering career while still in high school.  Unlike professions such as law or business, few students discover engineering as a career as undergraduates.  The workshops helped faculty to create introduction to engineering courses that are suitable as general education courses while still meeting the needs of those already committed to an engineering career.

The project conducted a series of six workshops.  These six workshops were attended by 107 people from 72 different institutions.  The project also organized a panel discussion for the annual conference of the American Society of Engineering Education.  The workshops addressed two topics: the overall structure of introductory courses in engineering and technology and design projects relevant to diverse groups of students.  The workshop helped participants develop a plan for a general-education introduction to engineering course open to both engineers and non-engineers.  These introductory engineering courses can serve both the general education needs of non-engineers and the career objectives of engineering students.  Critical factors in attracting and promoting courses to students with a tentative interest in engineering were outlined.  Participants were able to create an outline of a course structure consistent with their institutional environment.  Participants reviewed examples of successful implementations.  Issues addressed included: balancing technical depth with engineering breadth, teamwork issues, structuring design projects to include non-engineering majors, and assessment methods.

Another specific workshop objective emphasized the structuring of design projects in such a way as to increase the appeal of introduction to engineering courses for all students, not just those already committed to majoring in engineering.  A key challenge is making meaningful design projects accessible to students with limited prior exposure to engineering activities while still engaging and challenging better-prepared students.  The workshop advocated the themes of "engineering reasoning" and domain-situated design as organizing principles.  Engineering reasoning focuses on the broad set of practices engineers use to create technological systems.  A design domain consists of a representative system, major components, operating principles, and related applications.  Each design activity includes a domain familiarization project or projects to allow all students to gain the familiarity needed to carry out a design project.  In this way, those students without significant prior experience are not disadvantaged compared to other students.  The familiarization project is followed by an open-ended design problem within the domain.  This approach includes scaffolding to support novices while also containing relevant open-ended design elements to challenge the creativity of all students, including the more experienced.  Incorporating this framework makes it possible to appeal to the needs of students already anticipating a major in engineering as well as those with a more tentative interest in the subject.  The workshop conducted hands-on sessions to help participants adapt this framework in their introduction to engineering course materials.

A notable outcome of the workshops was the consensus among the participants that domain-situated design activities could help introduction to engineering courses to be effective for students with a tentative interest in engineering while still challenging well-prepared students already committed to an engineering career.  A total of 89% stated that the workshop's design project materials and information could be useful in their courses.  Surveys resulted in 88% concurring that supporting students with a tentative interest in engineering while engaging more committed and experienced students is a challenge for introduction to engineering courses.  Participants showed 86% agreement that domain-situated design activities could help introduction to engineering courses to be more effective for students with a tentative interest in engineering.

Results from participant surveys indicate that the workshops were viewed favorably and found to be valuable by the participants.  Participant survey results show that 83% of respondents either agreed or strongly agreed that the workshop helped them to understand key factors in attracting interest in engineering among non-engineers and those with a tentative interest in engineering.  Eighty-seven percent of respondents either agreed or strongly agreed that they would like to attract more students with a tentative interest in engineering into their introduction to engineering courses.  The majority of the workshop participants agreed with the idea that introduction to engineering courses open to all students could establish a broader path into the engineering profession and help attract more diversity into engineering.
